prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For refusing to buy any of my family members a christmas gift?
Now, based off of the title, you probably already think “Damn, this kid’s an asshole.” But here’s some context.

The week before Christmas, I received a $400 target gift card I won in a drawing.  I bragged about it on Instagram, where my sister follows me on, and of course, she saw it. She gave me a phone call and asked me who gave it to me, and I explain the situation, and tell her specifically NOT TO TELL MOM, as I knew it was bad enough that my sister knew already. She hangs up, and a few minutes later, my mother comes bursting into my room. She asks to see the gift card, and I hand it to her. She gives it back, then she says, obnoxiously, “You have to get something for me and (Sister’s name), That frustrated me enough, but I agreed, (I am VERY conservative, especially with my money.) 

Then when I was at target, getting my stuff plus what I WAS gonna get for my mom and sister, I get a phone call from my mom. 

Mom: “Oh, also, you have to get something for (Cousin 1’s name) and (Cousin 2’s name,) as well. Be thoughtful, don’t just get something cheap.” She said, even more obnoxiously 

(We were visiting my Uncle and Aunt for christmas, and my cousins are 6 and 2, so why the hell would I need to spend that much money on two more people I don’t and won’t see often?)

Me: “No thanks.” I then hung up the phone and ignored the rest of my mom’s texts and phone calls.

I spoiled myself, changing my mind about getting anyone else anything, because of how obnoxious everyone was being towards me after finding out what I had, so I spoiled myself. Bought myself a pair of airpods, GTA V, PlayStation Plus,a cheap laptop to do work on, and some new wrestling gear. Also bought a buddy of mine a bluetooth speaker, and spent the rest on candy and whatnot. 

Walked home and my mother was expecting that I got everyone a gift. Boy, was she shocked (despite our last phone call.) I got an ass chewing and she tried to guilt trip me, (unsuccessfully.) 

We were arguing then I just said “Maybe if you weren’t being so greedy about the situation, and kept your paws off of my money, I wouldn’t have changed my mind about getting you guys something!” (My exact words with some stuttering in it,) 

She then yelled at me a final time, marched to her room, and slammed her door. 

Typing that first paragraph made my blood boil, and reminded me of why I’m gonna keep all future assets private to me and me only. 

I’m 15 years old, if that will affect your criticism at all. 





"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong for not giving Christmas gifts to their family members. The scenario is that the author, a 15-year-old, got a $400 Target gift card. They told their sister about it after posting on Instagram. Then their mom found out and insisted they buy gifts for the sister and themselves, which the author agreed to. But then the mom added two more cousins, and the author changed their mind, bought gifts for a friend instead and kept the rest for themselves. The mom got upset and yelled.

So, the first thing to consider is the age of the author. At 15, they might not have a lot of independence in financial decisions, especially if they're still under their parents' care. The mom's reaction could be seen as trying to manage family traditions or expectations. The author's frustration with their mom's "greediness" and the mom's insistence on buying for cousins they don't see often might be a conflict point. 

Also, the author had initially agreed to buy gifts for the sister and mom but then the mom added more people. The author might feel pressured or that they're being taken advantage of. But is that a valid reason? In many families, there's an expectation to give gifts to close relatives. The author's age could mean they're not expected to have significant expenses, so maybe the mom thought $400 was a good opportunity to get gifts for multiple family members. 

The author's actions include changing their mind after agreeing, which could be seen as not following through. However, the initial agreement was under pressure, and the mom added more people after the fact. The author might not have had a clear understanding of how much to spend or if they were supposed to keep the money private. 

The key elements here are the expectations within the family, the author's autonomy over the gift card, and the communication between the author and their mom. The mom might have expected the gift card to be used for family gifts, while the author saw it as their own money. The author's decision to buy for a friend instead could be seen as a shift in priorities, but the mom's reaction is typical of parental expectations. 

I think the author is partially in the wrong because they did agree to buy gifts for the sister and mom, then reneged. However, their mom's behavior was also pushy, adding more people and being obnoxious. The 15-year-old might not have the financial independence to make such decisions, and the mom's guilt-tripping could be a factor. But the initial agreement and the author's change of heart might make them responsible for the disappointment. So, the answer might be A, but there are nuances. Alternatively, if the gift card was their own money, maybe they're justified. But since they're a minor, maybe the mom had a right to expect some use for the family. Hmm.
